Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Evan Joon Hyuk Park of Yale University to conduct a research project, entitled "Studying the visual cortex in active animals using optical probes," during the summer of 2012 at Osaka University in Osaka, Japan. The host scientist is Professor Tetsuya Yagi.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to further develop miniature microscopes and optical techniques to study the representation and transformation of visual information in the brain, particularly in the primary visual cortex. There are many questions about the visual cortex that still need to be answered and new technologies being developed are providing this opportunity.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project, entitled "Studying the visual cortex in active animals using optical probes," set out to study the representation and transformation of visual information in the brain, particularly in the primary visual cortex. The project involved implementing an imaging system developed during the PI's thesis work onto a rat to record neuronal activity using voltage sensitive dyes.

This was the first attempt at mounting the imaging system (composed of custom-designed image sensor, microscope and light source) onto the head of a rat. Various limitations of the initial design in the head-mount were discovered and addressed, which involved coming up with a novel method to secure the imaging system onto the head and a minor redesign of the head-mount and microscope.

Also, the imaging system was still slightly larger than optimal, and a complete redesign of the imaging system was performed. This involved designing a new printed circuit board in a smaller form factor, and applying a different method of soldering to assemble the tiny components onto the board.

Lastly, various experimental and animal preparation techniques were obtained from the collaborators. The PI learned about a unique animal preparation method where the optical probes are applied in the cortex in the dark by using a infrared imaging setup. This particular method results in a higher rate of success in the expression of the optical probes in animals during the experiement.

The result of the above works was a smaller and lighter overall imaging system that can be head-mounted securely on the skull of a rat to image the visual cortex.

During the EAPSI fellowship, the PI gained first-hand research experience in Japan, along with the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the country. Meaningful relationships were formed with the collaborator's lab, as well as other labs within Osaka University and Nara University. More importantly, through these networks, the PI was able to get in touch with the CEO of BrainVision and arrange a possible wafer sharing with the company on their next fabrication run. This collaboration gives the PI an access to advanced image sensor fabrication processes and design know-how to further improve the quality of the imaging system.
